introduction.p: In this chapter, we'll discuss the next level of complexity for equations by allowing our variables to have positive whole numbers as exponents, such as x^2+4x+3 or 3x^3-2x^2+3x-1 . Equations with this next level of complexity are examples of Polynomial Equations.

Something cool about polynomials is that most of the functions you can think of in the world, no matter how complicated, can be estimated by polynomial equations! This means that no matter how complicated something is, there is a way to estimate it with just the simple operations of addition, subtraction, multiplication, and positive whole number exponents! The image below shows a jagged complicated function in blue, along with a relatively nicer function in red that approximates it. This is the idea that polynomials can lead to!

You'll also learn in this chapter how to factor some polynomials. Factoring is a key process for solving equations because it lets us know where the function intersects the horizontal axis. Applications could be to find where your equation of revenue "breaks even"!

In , we defined a relation to be a collection of pairs of objects from two sets. In this section, we will talk about an important type of relation called a function.

li.p: define functions and explore different representations of functions
determine whether a relation is a function from various representations
determine the domain and range of functions

introduction.p: A function is a relation in which each input is related to exactly one output. Here, "input" and "output" refer to the first coordinate and the second coordinate, respectively.

For example, consider the following relation: \lbrace (-1,4),(0,7),(2,3),(3,3),(4,-2)\rbrace In this relation, the input of -1 is related to an output of 4, the input of 0 is related to an output of 7, etc. Since each input is related to exactly one output, this relation is a function.

statement.p: Determine whether the following relation is a function.

solution.p: Although most of the inputs correspond to exactly one output, the input of 3 has two outputs: 5 and 7. Since there is an input with more than one output, this relation is not a function.

introduction.p: In , we defined the domain of a relation to be the set of first components. A more standard way to define domain is that it is the set of all of the inputs. Similarly, the range of a relation is the set of all of its outputs.

statement.p: Determine whether the following relation is a function. State the domain and range of the relation.

solution.p: Since each input corresponds to exactly one output, this relation is a function. The domain is the set of all x-coordinates and the range is the set of all y-coordinates.
Note that 2 being the output for two different inputs does not violate the definition of a function.

subsection.title: Representations of Functions
subsection.p: All of the representations of relations can be used to represent functions as well. Each representation has unique characteristics that can be used to determine whether the relation is a function and to identify the domain and range.

statement.p: Determine whether the relation given by the table below is a function. State the domain and range.

solution.p: The inputs are the entries in the left column. Each input corresponds to exactly one output, so this is a function. The domain is all of the numbers in the left column, and the range is all the numbers in the right column.

statement.p: Determine whether the relation given by the table below is a function. State the domain and range.

solution.p: The input 5 appears in the table twice, and it has two different outputs. Since the input of 5 has more than one output, this is not a function.

subsection.p: The next two examples involve arrow diagrams. Pay special attention to the difference between the arrow diagram that represents the function and the arrow diagram that represents a non-function.

statement.p: Determine whether the relation given by the arrow diagram below is a function. State the domain and range.

solution.p: In an arrow diagram, the arrows are drawn from an input to its correspond output. All of the inputs (the numbers in the left bubble) have an arrow taking them to exactly on number. Since each input corresponds to exactly one output, this relation is a function.

statement.p: Determine whether the relation given by the arrow diagram below is a function. State the domain and range.

solution.p: In this relation, there are two arrows pointing out of -3. This means that the input -3 has two outputs, namely 2 and -4. Since there is an input with more than one output, this relation is not a function.

subsection.p: One of the most useful ways to represent a relation is with a graph. For each point on the graph, the input is the x-coordinate and the output is the y-coordinate. If one input has two different outputs, then there would be two distinct points with the same x-value. Since they have the same x-value, one would be directly above the other. For example, suppose we have a relation with the ordered pairs (3,1) and (3,6). The input of 3 corresponds to two outputs, 1 and 6, so this is not a function. Graphically, we have

We can visually determine whether a graph represents a function using the vertical line test. If any vertical line intersects the graph more than once, then the graph does not represent a function. Returning to the previous graph, we can see that this is not a function since the points (3,1) and (3,6) intersect the same vertical line.

statement.p: Determine whether the relation given by the graph below is a function. State the domain and range.

solution.p: Since no vertical line can be drawn to intersect two points, this relation passes the vertical line test and is therefore a function.

statement.p: Determine whether the relation given by the graph below is a function. State the domain and range.

solution.p: The vertical line x=2 intersects two points of the graph, so this relation fails the vertical line test and is therefore not a function.

subsection.title: Function Notation
subsection.p: With the definition of a function comes special notation. If we consider each x-value to be the input that produces exactly one output, then we can use function notation:
The notation f(x) is read as, âf of xâ and should not be confused with multiplication. If f(x)=y is a function, we say that y is a function of x.

Algebra frequently involves functions, and so the notation becomes useful when performing common tasks. Here f is the function name, and f(x) denotes the value in the range associated with the value x in the domain. Functions are often named with different letters; some common names for functions are f, g, h, C, and R, but really any letter can be used for the name of a function. We can use function notation to describe a function given in any representation, but it is most frequently seen with equation. For example, consider the function f(x)=2x-4. This function relates each input x to the output 2x-4. If we are looking for the output for a particular input, we can evaluate the function by plugging that value of x in. For instance,
Here the compact notation f(-3)=-10 indicates that where x=-3 (the input), the function results in y=-10 (the output).

From above, we can see that our output depends on our input. Another way we define this is to call our input x the independent variable and our output y the dependent variable. Indeed, above, our function's output was dependent upon what the input was - when we put in -3, we got out the answer -10.

statement.p: Consider the function M=53+14t where M represents miles from home on Gabby's bike trip as a function of t, the number of hours since Gabby left her office. Which is the independent variable, and which is the dependent variable?

solution.p: When translating word problems to equations it may help to remember that the phrase "a function of", tells us our input, or independent variable is time t.
The independent variable is t, and the dependent variable is M.

subsection.p: Function notation streamlines the task of evaluating. For example, use the function h defined by h(x)=\frac{1}{2}x-3 to evaluate for x-values in the set {-2,0,7}.
Given any function defined by h(x)=y the input x can be any algebraic expression. For example:

statement.p: Given g(x)=x^2, find g(-2), g\left(\frac{1}{2}\right), and g(x+h).

solution.p: When evaluating, it is a best practice to begin by replacing the variables with parentheses and then substitute the appropriate values. This helps with the order of operations when simplifying expressions.

subsection.p: At this point, it is important to note that, in general, f(x+h)\neq f(x)+f(h). The previous example, where g(x)=x^2, illustrates this nicely.

statement.p: Given k(x)=\sqrt{2x+4}, find k(-2), and k(0).

subsection.p: Sometimes the output is given and we are asked to find the input.

statement.p: Given f(x)=-3x+10, for what values of x is f(x)=4?

solution.p: Here we're given the output and we're looking for the corresponding input(s). In other words, we're given f(x) and are looking for x.
Therefore f(2)=4.

subsection.p: We can use function notation to describe functions presented in other forms, including graphs, tables and diagrams.

statement.p: The graph below represents g(x). Find g(-1),\, g(0), and g(3). For what value(s) is g(x) equal to 3?

solution.p: The notation g(-1) means that we are looking for the output associated with the input of -1. Graphically, this means that x=-1 and we're looking for the output of such point on the graph. The only point on the graph with an input of -1 is y=2. Therefore g(-1)=2.
Similarly, we find that g(0)=1 and g(3)=1.

On the other hand, to find the value(s) for which g(x) is equal to 3, we are looking for input(s) associated with the output of 3. Graphically, this means that y=3 and we're looking for the input of such points on the graph. From the graph, we can see that g(-2)=3 and g(4)=3.

introduction.p:
A polynomial is an expression made up of a single term or sum of terms with only one variable in which each exponent is a positive whole number. For example,
2x^3, \hspace{.5cm} 8x^4-x^2+9, \hspace{.5cm} x^9, \hspace{.5cm} x+4
are all polynomials, while
x^{-3}, \hspace{.5cm} 4x^{0.5}+2, \hspace{.5cm} \dfrac{1}{x^4}
are not polynomials. Polynomials define functions of the form

Here a_n represents any real number and n represents any whole number. The degree of a polynomial with one variable is the largest exponent of all the terms. Typically, we arrange terms of polynomials in descending order based on their degree and classify them as follows:

In this course, we call any polynomial with degree higher than 3 an nth-degree polynomial. For example, if the degree is 4, we call it a fourth-degree polynomial; if the degree is 5, we call it a fifth-degree polynomial, and so on.
When a polynomial is arranged in descending order based on their degree, we call the first term of the sum the leading term, and the coefficient part of this term is called the leading coefficient.

statement.p: Given f(x)=3x^2+5x+17, g(x)=15x^{24}+36x^{22}+17x^4+31, h(x)=11x^2+17x^3+121x, j(x)=5x^3+2x+4x^3+3x+5, and k(x)=25, state the degree, leading term, and leading coefficient of each polynomial.

solution.p: Looking at f(x), we see that the highest power of x is 2, so the degree is 2. The term with the highest degree is 3x^2, meaning this is our leading term, and the coefficient of this term is 3, which means this is our leading coefficient.

Looking at g(x), we see that the highest power of x is 24, so the degree is 24. The term with the highest degree is 15x^{24}, meaning this is our leading term, and the coefficient of this term is 15, which means this is our leading coefficient.

Looking at h(x), we see that the polynomial is not arranged in descending order of degree, so we will rearrange first. h(x)=17x^3+11x^2+121x Now we see that the highest power of x is 3, so the degree is 3. The term with the highest degree is 17x^{3}, meaning this is our leading term, and the coefficient of this term is 17, which means this is our leading coefficient.

Looking at j(x), we see that the polynomial is not arranged in descending order of degree, so we will rearrange first. j(x)=5x^3+4x^3+2x+3x+5=9x^3+5x+5 Now we see that the highest power of x is 3, so the degree is 3. The term with the highest degree is 9x^{3}, meaning this is our leading term, and the coefficient of this term is 9, which means this is our leading coefficient.

Looking at k(x), we have just a constant. This is the same as k(x)=25\cdot 1=25x^0, so we see that the highest power of x is 0, so the degree is 0. The term with the highest degree is 25x^0=25, meaning this is our leading term, and the coefficient of this term is 25, which means this is our leading coefficient.

statement.p: Given f(x)=x^2-8x+17, find f(2) and f(4).

solution.p: Replace each instance of x with the value given inside the parentheses.
We can write f(2)=5 and f(4)=1. Remember that f(x)=y and so we can interpret these results on the graph as follows:
We find that f(2)=5 and f(4)=1.

introduction.p: One useful application of polynomials appears in physics. The height of an object launched upward, ignoring the effects of air resistance, can be modeled with the following quadratic function:

With this formula, the height h(t) can be calculated at any given time t after the object is launched. The letter g represents acceleration due to gravity on the surface of the Earth, which is 32 feet per second squared (or, using metric units, g = 9.8 meters per second squared). The parameter v_0 pronounced âv-naught,â or sometimes âv-zero,â represents the initial velocity of the object. The parameter s_0 represents the initial height from which the object was launched.

statement.p: An object is launched from the ground at a speed of 64 feet per second. Write a function that models the height of the object and use it to calculate the object's height at 1 second and at 3.5 seconds.

solution.p: We know that the acceleration due to gravity is g=32 feet per second squared and we are given the initial velocity v_0=64 feet per second. Since the object is launched from the ground, the initial height is s_0=0 feet. Create the mathematical model by substituting these coefficients into the following formula:
Use this model to calculate the height of the object at 1 second and 3.5 seconds.
Our function is h(t)=-16t^2+64t. This tells us that at 1 second the object is at a height of 48 feet, and at 3.5 seconds it is at a height of 28 feet.

statement.p: An object is dropped from a height of 6 meters. Write a function that models the height of the object and use it to calculate the object's height 1 second after it is dropped.

subsection.title: Adding and Subtracting Polynomials
subsection.p: On occasion a special notation is used to indicate addition and subtraction of functions. This mentioned here in the book so you have some exposure to the notation. The notation is as follows:
When using function notation, be careful to group the entire function and add or subtract accordingly.

statement.p: Given f(x)=x^3-5x-7 and g(x)=3x^2+7x-2, find f(x)+g(x) and f(x)-g(x).

solution.p: The notation f(x)+g(x) indicates that we should add the given expressions.

The notation f(x)-g(x) indicates that we should subtract the given expressions. When subtracting, the parentheses become very important. We can eliminate them after applying the distributive property.
Our solutions are f(x)+g(x)=x^3+3x^2+2x-9 and f(x)-g(x)= x^3-3x^2-12x-5.

subsection.p: We may be asked to evaluate the sum or difference of two functions. We have the option to first find the sum or difference in general and then use the resulting function to evaluate for the given variable, or evaluate each first and then find the sum or difference.

statement.p: Evaluate f(3)-g(3) given f(x)=5x^2-x+4 and g(x)=x^2+2x-3.

solution.p: First, find (f-g)(x).
Now we substitute 3 in for the variable x.
Our solution is f(3)-g(3)=34.
Alternatively, we could have found f(3) and g(3) and then subtracted the results to obtain our answer.

subsection.p: Note: If multiple values are to be evaluated, it is best to find the sum or difference in general first and then use it to evaluate.

subsection.title: Multiplying and Dividing Polynomials
subsection.p: The notation that is sometimes used to indicate multiplication and division of functions follows:
In this book we will simply consider multiplication notated by f(x)\cdot g(x) and division notated by \frac{f(x)}{g(x)}, \text{ where }g(x)\neq 0.

statement.p: Given f(x)=15x^4-9x^3+6x^2 and g(x)=3x^2, find f(x)\cdot g(x) and \frac{f(x)}{g(x)}.

solution.p: Apply the distributive property and simplify.
For this quotient, assume x\neq 0.
Our solutions are f(x)\cdot g(x)=45x^6-27x^5+18x^4 and \frac{f(x)}{g(x)}= 5x^2-3x+2.

statement.p: Given f(x)=6x-5 and g(x)=3x^2-2x-1, find f(0)\cdot g(0) and f(-1)\cdot g(-1).

solution.p: To find f(x)\cdot g(x), we need to apply the distributive property multiple times. First, we distribute 6x-5 to each of the terms in g(x) and then distribute the terms to each of the 6x-5.
Now we substitute 0 and -1 in for the variable x.
Our solutions are f(0)\cdot g(0)=5 and f(-1)\cdot g(-1)=-44.

statement.p: Given f(x)=x^3+x-8 and g(x)=2x^2-x+9, find f(x)\cdot g(x).

introduction.p: The process of writing a number or expression as a product is called factoring. If we write the monomial 8x^7=2x^5\cdot 4x^2, we say that the product 2x^5\cdot 4x^2 is a factorization of 8x^7 and that 2x^5 and 4x^2 are factors. Typically there are many ways to factor a monomial. Given two or more monomials, it will be useful to find the greatest common factor (GCF) of each. The GCF of the monomials is the product of the common variable factors and the GCF of the coefficients.

Next we determine the common variable factors with the smallest exponents.

subsection.title: Factoring by Grouping
subsection.p: In this section, we outline a technique for factoring polynomials with four terms. First, review a preliminary example where the terms have a common binomial factor.

statement.p: Factor 7x(3x-2)-(3x-2).

solution.p: We begin by rewriting the second term -(3x-2) as -1(3x-2). Next, consider (3x-2) as a common binomial factor and factor it out as follows:
Factoring results in 7x(3x-2)-(3x-2)=(3x-2)(7x-1).

subsection.p: Factoring by grouping is a technique that enables us to factor polynomials with four terms into a product of binomials. This involves an intermediate step where a common binomial factor will be factored out. For example, suppose we wish to factor
We begin by grouping the first two terms and the last two terms. Then factor out the GCF of each grouping:
In this form, the polynomial is a binomial with a common binomial factor, (x-4).
We can check our answer by multiplying:

statement.p: Factor the polynomial 24a^4-18a^3-20a+15 by grouping.

solution.p: The GCF for the first group, 24a^4-18a^3, is 6a^3. We have to choose 5 or -5 to factor out of the second group.

Factoring out +5 does not result in a common binomial factor. If we choose to factor out -5, then we obtain a common binomial factor and can proceed. Note that when factoring out a negative number, we change the signs of the factored terms.

subsection.p: Sometimes we must first rearrange the terms in order to obtain a common factor.

statement.p: Factor ab-2a^2b+a^3-2b^2.

solution.p: If we simply factor the GCF out of the first group and last group, we do not get a common binomial factor.
We must rearrange the terms, searching for a grouping that produces a common factor. In this example, we have a workable grouping if we switch the terms a^3 and ab.
Factoring ab-2a^2b+a^3-2b^2 results in ab-2a^2b+a^3-2b^2= (a-2b)(a^2+b).

statement.p: Factor x^3-x^2y-xy+y^2.

Factoring such polynomials is a topic for a more advanced algebra course. For now, we will limit our attempt to factor four-term polynomials to using the factor by grouping technique.

introduction.p: In the previous section, we looked at three factoring techniques. In this section, we will learn a fourth factoring technique that allows up to factor a type of polynomial called a trinomial.

li.p: learn the ac-method of factoring

assemblage.title: Supplemental Videos
assemblage.p:
The main topics of this section are also presented in the following videos:
What is the ac-Method

introduction.p: Some trinomials of the form ax^2+bx+c can be factored as a product of binomials using a technique called the ac-method. If such a trinomial can be factored, then the middle term, bx, can be replaced with two terms with coefficients whose sum is b and whose product is ac. This substitution results in an equivalent expression with four terms that can be factored by grouping.
If factors of ac cannot be found to add up to b then the trinomial is prime.

statement.p: Factor x^2+12x+20.

solution.p: Here, a=1, b=12, and c=20, so we need to find two numbers whose sum is 12 and whose product is 20. To do this, list all factorizations of 20 and search for factors whose sum equals 12.
Choose 20 = 2 \cdot 10 because 2 + 10 = 12. Therefore, 12x=2x+10x, and we can write x^2+\alert{12x}+20=x^2+\alert{2x+10x}+20.
We can now factor the equivalent expression by grouping.
Our factored form is (x+10)(x+2).
We check by multiplying the two binomials:
Note: We made a choice in the above problem to write 12x=2x+10x. What would happen if we instead had written 12x=10x+2x? Notice that in the following calculation the answer is equivalent.
We factor the equivalent expression by grouping.

introduction.p: Since multiplication is commutative, the order of the factors does not matter.
If the last term of the trinomial is positive, then either both of the constant factors must be negative or both must be positive.

statement.p: Factor x^2y^2-7xy+12.

solution.p: Even though there are multiple variables, this technique will still work. Here, a=1, b=-7, and c=12, so we need to find two numbers whose sum is -7 and whose product is 12. Notice that in this case, both numbers must be negative.
Choose 12 = -3 \cdot -4 because -3 -4 = -7. Therefore, -7xy=-3xy-4xy, and we can write x^2y^2\alert{-7xy}+12=x^2y^2\alert{-3xy-4xy}+12.
We factor the equivalent expression by grouping.
Our factored form is (xy-4)(xy-3).
We check by multiplying the two binomials.

introduction.p: The check is very important and is something you should plan to do on every single problem.
Keep in mind that some polynomials are what is called prime. For example, consider the trinomial x^2+3x+20 and the factors of 20:

There are no integer factors of 20 whose sum is 3. Therefore, the original trinomial cannot be factored as a product of two binomials with integer coefficients. The trinomial is prime, that is, it cannot be factored with integer terms.
In all of the examples we've seen so far, the leading coefficient has been 1. We will now see what happens when the leading coefficient is not 1.

statement.p: Factor 18x^2-31x+6 using the ac-method.

solution.p: Here a=18,\, b=-31, and c=6.
Now we factor 108, and search for factors whose sum is -31.
In this case, the sum of the factors -27 and -4 equals the middle coefficient, -31. Therefore, -31x=-27x-4x, and we can write
We factor the equivalent expression by grouping.
Our factored form is (2x-3)(9x-2).

statement.p: Factor 4x^2y^2-7xy-15 using the ac-method.

solution.p: Here a=4,\, b=-7, and c=-15.
Now we factor -60, and search for factors whose sum is -7.
In this case, the sum of the factors 5 and -12 equals the middle coefficient, -7. Therefore, we replace -7xy with 5xy-12xy.
Our factored form is (4xy+5)(xy-3).

statement.p: Factor 5x^2+16xy+3y^2.

solution.p: Here a=5,\, b=16y, and c=3y^2.
Now we factor 15y^2, and search for factors whose sum is 16y.
In this case, the sum of the factors 1y and 15y equals the middle coefficient, 16y. Therefore, we replace 16xy with 15xy+1xy.
Our factored form is (5x+y)(x+3y).

statement.p: Factor 18a^2b^2-ab-4.

solution.p: Here a=18,\, b=-1, and c=-4.
Now we factor -72, and search for factors whose sum is -1.
In this case, the sum of the factors 8 and -9 equals the middle coefficient, -1. Therefore, we replace -ab with 8ab-9ab.
Our factored form is (9ab+4)(2ab-1).

statement.p: Factor 12y^3-26y^2-10y.

solution.p: First, we will factor out the GCF.

After factoring out 2y, the coefficients of the resulting trinomial are smaller and have fewer factors. We can factor the resulting trinomial using 6=2(3) and 5=(5)(1). Notice that these factors can produce -13 in two ways:
Since the last term is -5, the correct combination requires the factors 1 and 5 to be opposite signs. Here we use 2(1) = 2 and 3(-5) = -15 because the sum is -13 and the product of (1)(-5) = -5.
We check as follows.
The factor 2y is part of the factored form of the original expression; be sure to include it in the answer.
Our factored form is 2y(2y-5)(3y+1).

statement.p: Factor 2x^2-9x-5 using the ac-method.

solution.p: Since ac=(2)(-5)=-10 and b=-9, we need two numbers that multiply to -10 and sum to -9. Two such numbers are -10 and 1, so we can write -9x as -10x+1x and factor by grouping.

statement.p: Factor 6x^2+7x-10 using the ac-method.

solution.p: Since ac=(6)(-10)=-60 and b=7, we need two numbers that multiply to -60 and sum to 7. Two such numbers are 12 and -5, so we can write 7x as 7x=12x-5x and factor by grouping.

statement.p: Factor 9x^2+6x-8 using the ac-method.

solution.p: Since ac=(9)(-8)=-72 and b=6, we need two numbers that multiply to -72 and sum to 6. Two such numbers are 12 and -6, so we can write 6x as 12x-6x and factor by grouping.

introduction.p: In the previous sections, we defined what it means to factor a polynomial and learned several factoring techniques. While factoring might seem like it's counterproductive to simplifying expressions, it does have useful applications. In this section, we will use factoring in order to solve polynomial equations.

li.p: review general factoring strategies
learn the zero factor principle
use the zero factor principle to solve polynomial equations

assemblage.title: Supplemental Videos

Review of Factoring, the Zero Factor Principle, and Roots of a Polynomial

subsection.title: Reviewing General Factoring Strategies
subsection.p: We have learned various techniques for factoring polynomials with up to four terms. The challenge is to identify the type of polynomial and then decide which method to apply. The following outlines a general guideline for factoring polynomials:

li.p: Check for common factors. If the terms have common factors, then factor out the greatest common factor (GCF).
If there are no common factors, determine the number of terms in the polynomial.
If the polynomial has four terms, try to factor by grouping.
If it is a trinomial (3 terms), try using the ac method.
If it is a binomial (2 terms), check if it is a difference of squares.
Look for factors that can be factored further.
Check by multiplying.

subsection.p: If an expression has a GCF, then factor this out first. Doing so is often overlooked and typically results in factors that are easier to work with. Furthermore, look for the resulting factors to factor further; many factoring problems require more than one step. A polynomial is completely factored when none of the factors can be factored further.
If none of these techniques work, it might be the case that the polynomial is prime, or does not factor.

subsection.title: Solving Polynomial Equations by Factoring
subsection.p: In this section, we will review a technique that can be used to solve certain polynomial equations. We begin with the zero factor principle:

md.mrow: a\cdot b=0 \text{ if and only if }a=0\text{ or }b=0

subsection.p: The zero factor principle is true for any number of factors that make up an equation. In other words, if any product is equal to zero, then at least one of the variable factors must be equal to zero. If an expression is equal to zero and can be factored into linear factors, then we will be able to set each factor equal to zero and solve each equation.

warning.p: The zero factor principle is sometimes called the zero product property.

section.title: Algebraic Fractions

introduction.p: In the previous section, we saw a useful application of factoring polynomials, namely solving polynomial equations. In this section, we will explore another important application of factoring: algebraic fractions. Algebraic fractions are a special type of function, and factoring will allow us to simplify them as well as perform the four basic operations on them.

li.p: define and simplify algebraic fractions
identify the domain of algebraic fractions
add, subtract, multiply, and divide algebraic fractions

assemblage.title: Supplemental Videos
assemblage.p:
The main topics of this section are also presented in the following videos:
Simplifying Algebraic Fractions, Restrictions and Domain, and Operations on Algebraic Fractions

section.subsection:
Identifying Restrictions and Simplifying
Algebraic fractions, or rational functions, have the form
r(x)=\frac{p(x)}{q(x)},
where p(x) and q(x) are polynomials and q(x)\neq 0. The domain of an algebraic fraction will be identified with the domain or the rational function it defines and consists of all real numbers x except those where the denominator q(x)=0. Restrictions on the domain are real numbers for which the expression is undefined. For example, consider the function
f(x)=\frac{(x-1)(x-3)}{(x-2)(x-3)}\text{.}
This is an algebraic fraction since (once expanded) both the numerator and denominator are polynomials. To find the domain, we need to consider what values of x will make the denominator equal to zero; in other words, the domain of this function is everything except the value(s) that solve 0=(x-2)(x-3). Applying the zero-factor property, we have
\begin{aligned} x-2\amp =0 \: \: \: \: \: \amp \text{ or }\: \: \: \: \: x-3\amp =0\\ x\amp =2\amp x\amp =3 \end{aligned}
Therefore, the original function is defined for any real number except 2 and 3. We can express its domain using notation.
x\neq 2,3 \: \: \: \: \: \text{ or }\: \: \: \: \: (-\infty, 2)\cup(2,3)\cup(3,\infty)
The restrictions to the domain of an algebraic fraction are determined by the denominator. Once the restrictions are determined we can cancel factors and obtain an equivalent function.
Quadrants of the Plane
It is important to note that 1 is not a restriction to the domain because the expression is defined as 0 when the numerator is 0. In fact, x=1 is a root. This function is graphed below.
Quadrants of the Plane
Notice that there is a vertical asymptote at the restriction x=2 and the graph is left undefined at the restriction x=3 as indicated by the open dot, or hole, in the graph. Graphing algebraic fractions in general is beyond the scope of this course. However, it is useful at this point to know that the restrictions are an important part of the graph of algebraic fractions.
State the restrictions and simplify the algebraic fraction g(x)=\frac{24x^7}{6x^5}.
Since g(x) is an algebraic fraction, it is undefined, or restricted, where its denominator is zero. Since the only solution of 6x^5=0 is x=0, the function is undefined where x is 0.
g(0)=\frac{24(0)^7}{6(0)^5}=\frac{0}{0} \: \: \: \alert{\text{Undefined}}
Therefore, the domain consists of all real numbers x, where x\neq 0. With this understanding, we can simplify by reducing the rational expression to lowest terms. Cancel common factors.
g(x)=\frac{24x^7}{6x^5}=\frac{4x^7}{x^5}=4x^2
Our answer is g(x)=4x^2, where x\neq 0.
State the restrictions and simplify the algebraic fraction g(x)=\frac{2x^2+5x-3}{4x^2-1}.
Before we can identify the restrictions and simplify the function, we need to factor both the numerator and the denominator.
\begin{aligned} g(x)\amp =\frac{2x^2+5x-3}{4x^2-1}\\ \amp =\frac{(2x-1)(x+3)}{(2x+1)(2x-1)} \end{aligned}
Since g(x) is an algebraic fraction, it is undefined, or restricted, where its denominator is zero. Applying the zero-factor principle, we have
\begin{aligned} 2x+1\amp =0 \: \: \: \: \: \amp \text{ or }\: \: \: \: \: 2x-1\amp =0\\ 2x\amp =-1\amp 2x\amp =1\\ x\amp =-\frac{1}{2}\amp x\amp =\frac{1}{2} \end{aligned}
Therefore, the domain consists of all real numbers x, where x\neq -\frac{1}{2},\frac{1}{2}. With this understanding, we can simplify by reducing the rational expression to lowest terms. Cancel common factors.
g(x)=\frac{(2x-1)(x+3)}{(2x+1)(2x-1)}=\frac{x+3}{2x+1}
Our answer is g(x)=\frac{x+3}{2x+1}, where x\neq -\frac{1}{2},\frac{1}{2}.
Occasionally we will have to factor out a negative one to simplify an algebraic fraction as much as possible.
State the restrictions and simplify the algebraic fraction g(x)=\frac{25-x^2}{x^2-10x+25}.
First, we factor the numerator and denominator.
\begin{aligned} g(x)\amp =\frac{25-x^2}{x^2-10x+25}\\ \amp =\frac{(5-x)(5+x)}{(x-5)(x-5)}\\ \amp = \frac{\alert{-1\cdot (x-5)}(5+x)}{(x-5)(x-5)}\\ \amp=\frac{-1(5+x)}{(x-5)}\\ \amp = -\frac{x+5}{x-5}\\ \end{aligned}
Our answer is g(x)=-\frac{x+5}{x-5}, where x\neq 5.
It is important to remember that we can only cancel factors of a product. A common mistake is to cancel terms.
State the restrictions and simplify f(x)=\frac{x-2x^2}{4x^4-x^2}.
Before we can identify the restrictions and simplify the function, we need to factor both the numerator and the denominator.
\begin{aligned} f(x)\amp= \frac{x-2x^2}{4x^4-x^2}\\ \amp= \frac{x(1-2x)}{x^2(2x+1)(2x-1)} \\ \amp= \frac{-x(2x-1)}{x^2(2x+1)(2x-1)} \end{aligned}
Since f(x) is an algebraic fraction, it is undefined, or restricted, where its denominator is zero. Applying the zero-factor principle, we find that the restrictions are x=0,\frac{1}{2},-\frac{1}{2}.
Therefore, the domain consists of all real numbers x, where x\neq 0,\frac{1}{2},-\frac{1}{2}. With this understanding, we can simplify by reducing the rational expression to lowest terms. Cancel common factors.
f(x)=\frac{-x(2x-1)}{x^2(2x+1)(2x-1)}=\frac{-1}{x(2x+1)}
Our answer is f(x)=-\frac{1}{x(2x+1)}, where x\neq 0,\frac{1}{2},-\frac{1}{2}.
In some examples, we will make a broad assumption that the denominator is nonzero. When we make that assumption, we do not need to determine the restrictions.
Given f(x)=x^2-2x+5, simplify \frac{f(x)-f(3)}{ax-3a}. Assume all denominators are nonzero.
First, we calculate f(3).
\begin{aligned} f(3)\amp = (3)^2-2(3)+5\\ \amp = 9-6+5\\ \amp =3+5\\ \amp =8. \end{aligned}
Now we substitute into the quotient.
\begin{aligned} \frac{f(x)-f(3)}{ax-3a}\amp = \frac{x^2-2x+5-8}{ax-3a}\\ \amp = \frac{x^2-2x-3}{ax-3a}\\ \amp =\frac{(x+1)(x-3)}{a(x-3)}\\ \amp =\frac{x+1}{a} \end{aligned}
Our answer is \frac{f(x)-f(3)}{ax-3a}=\frac{x+1}{a}.

subsection.title: Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions
subsection.p: Recall from Numbers and Operations that to multiply two fractions, we can multiply the numerators together, multiply the denominators together, and then reduce. Multiplying rational expressions is performed in a similar manner. In general, given polynomials P, Q, R, and S, where Q\neq 0 and S\neq 0, we have
The restrictions to the domain of a product consist of the restrictions of each function.

statement.p: Given f(x)=\frac{9x^2-25}{x-5} and g(x)=\frac{x^2-2x-15}{3x+5}, find f(x)\cdot g(x) and determine the restrictions on the domain.

solution.p: In this case, the domain of f consists of all real numbers except 5, and the domain of g consists of all real numbers except -\frac{5}{3}. Therefore, the domain of the product consists of all real numbers except 5 and -\frac{5}{3}. Multiply the functions and then simplify the result.
Our answer is f(x)\cdot g(x)=(3x-5)(x+3) where x\neq 5,-\frac{5}{3}.

subsection.p:
To divide two fractions, we multiply by the reciprocal of the divisor. Dividing rational expressions is performed in a similar manner. In general, given polynomials P, Q, R, and S, where Q
eq 0, R
eq 0, and S
eq 0, we have
The restrictions to the domain of a quotient will consist of the restrictions of each function as well as the restrictions on the reciprocal of the divisor.

statement.p: Given f(x)=\frac{2x^2+13x-7}{x^2-4x-21} and g(x)=\frac{2x^2+5x-3}{49-x^2}, find \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} and determine the restrictions on the domain.

solution.p: We'll start by setting up the quotient and factoring each polynomial.

To find the restrictions, we need to find the restrictions of f(x), g(x), as well as the reciprocal of g(x). The restrictions of f(x) are -3 and 7, and the restrictions of g(x) are 7 and -7, and the reciprocal of g(x) has restrictions of -3 and \frac{1}{2}. Therefore, the domain of this quotient consists of all real numbers except -3, \frac{1}{2}, 7 and -7.
Next, to simplify the quotient, we perform the division and reduce.
Our answer is \left(\frac{f}{g}\right)(x)=-\frac{(x+7)^2}{(x+3)^2} where x\neq -3,\frac{1}{2},7,-7.

statement.p: Given f(x)=\frac{2x+5}{3x^2+14x-5} and g(x)=\frac{6x^2+13x-5}{x+5}, find \left(\frac{f}{g}\right)(x) and determine the restrictions on the domain.

solution.p: Our answer is \left(\frac{f}{g}\right)(x)=\frac{1}{(3x-1)^2} where x\neq -5,-\frac{5}{2},\frac{1}{3}.

subsection.title: Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions
subsection.p: Recall from Numbers and Operations that to multiply two fractions, we need a common denominator and then we can simply add or subtract the numerators and write the result over the common denominator. When working with rational expressions, the common denominator will be a polynomial. In general, given polynomials P, Q, and R, where Q\neq 0, we have the following:
The set of restrictions to the domain of a sum or difference of rational expressions consists of the restrictions to the domains of each expression.

statement.p: Perform the subtraction \frac{4x}{x^2-64}-\frac{3x+8}{x^2-64} and keep track of restrictions on the domain.

solution.p: Since the denominators are the same, we can subtract the numerators and write the result over the common denominator. Take care to distribute the negative 1.
Our solution is \frac{1}{x+8} for all real numbers x\neq \pm 8.

conclusion.p: To add or subtract rational expressions with unlike denominators, we first find equivalent expressions with common denominators. We do this just as we have with fractions. If the denominators of fractions are relatively prime, then the least common denominator (LCD) is their product. For example,
Multiply each fraction by the appropriate form of 1 to obtain equivalent fractions with a common denominator.
In general, given polynomials P, Q, R, and S, where Q\neq 0 and S\neq 0, we have the following:

statement.p: Given f(x)=\frac{5x}{3x+1} and g(x)=\frac{2}{x+1}, find f(x)+g(x) and determine the restrictions.

solution.p: Here the LCD is the product of the denominators (3x+1)(x+1). We multiply by the appropriate factors to obtain rational expressions with a common denominator before adding.

The domain of f consists all real numbers except -\frac{1}{3}, and the domain of g consists of all real numbers except -1. Therefore, the domain of f + g consists of all real numbers except -1 and -\frac{1}{3}.
Our solution is \frac{(5x+1)(x+2)}{(3x+1)(x+1)} for all real numbers x\neq -1,-\frac{1}{3}.

conclusion.p: It is not always the case that the LCD is the product of the given denominators. Typically, the denominators are not relatively prime; thus determining the LCD requires some thought. Begin by factoring all denominators. The LCD is the product of all factors with the highest power.

statement.p: Given f(x)=\frac{3x}{3x-1} and g(x)=\frac{4-14x}{3x^2-4x+1}, find f-g and determine the restrictions.

solution.p: To determine the LCD, factor the denominator of g.
In this case the LCD=(3x-1)(x-1). Multiply f by 1 in the form of \frac{(x-1)}{(x-1)} to obtain equivalent algebraic fractions with a common denominator and then subtract.

The domain of f consists all real numbers except \frac{1}{3}, and the domain of g consists of all real numbers except 1 and \frac{1}{3}. Therefore, the domain of f - g consists of all real numbers except 1 and \frac{1}{3}.
Our solution is \frac{x+4}{x-1} for all real numbers x\neq 1, \frac{1}{3}.

statement.p: Simplify \frac{-2x}{x+6}-\frac{3x}{6-x}-\frac{18(x-2)}{x^2-36} and determine the restrictions.

solution.p: Our solution is \frac{x+6}{x-6} for all real numbers x\neq \pm 6.

statement.p: Simplify \frac{x+1}{(x-1)^2}-\frac{2}{x^2-1}-\frac{4}{(x+1)(x-1)^2} and determine the restrictions.

solution.p: Our solution is \frac{1}{x-1} for all real numbers x\neq \pm 1.
